data.text: Only Front Panniers on a Bikepacking Bike
Ever ridden with panniers on the front forks only?
I thing having fat front end gives you that water droplet aero benefit. Also weight on front good for steep hills
data.author: Don Julius

data.text: Ever ridden that setup? I‚Äôm curious! Always had rear only panniers
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: up or down steep hills? at full weight thats a big difference
data.author: Hans Moravec

data.text: yes, I was touring the highlands for a month. Fully loaded, most of the weight up front. One thing I am changing is bringing the rando bag and panniers closer to the centre, because I puched them all the way up front in order to fit bottle, food and tools behing. Going to store them elsewhere and shift the weight closer to the rider but still in front where it is now. Was tempted to get wider bars but for roads currently ok. Its just the weight was hanging too much in front.
data.author: Don Julius

data.text: Great looking setup üòé
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: going up hills really helps having weight in front. I remember first time I went out bikepacking, all the weight was in the back, I was struggling to keep the front down when going up steep hills
data.author: Don Julius

data.text: thanks, I love to look good hehe
data.author: Don Julius

data.text: What were the effects of having the weight so far forward? Thanks.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: I felt like it was harder to balance the steering, more work, thats why I was considering wider bars. Luckily panniers and rando bag are adjustable, so if I bring them backwards 2-3 inches it will make a big difference. I felt like I was balancing the weight on my nose.
data.author: Don Julius

data.text: Yes, evens out the weight.
data.author: Michele Hedrick

data.text: Yes. Frame bag, seat bag too. The theory is that you want more weight on the front.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck
Jason Roussel

data.text: Yes. It's great for off road and steep climbs. Not my first choice for road primary riding however
data.author: Jason Roussel

data.text: Yes. I like the way my bike handles that way.

data.text: Yes, I have used from panniers only. So has my wife. Handling is better even on pavement.

data.text: Good tips

data.text: I have only ridden with front panniers and a saddle bag
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: Yes. My Salsa Vaya responds well to small panniers on the fork, with a frame bag and just a saddle pack in the rear, for an overall light weight set up. When I have the rear rack on and big panniers in the back, that works too but there is a tail wagging the dog effect. Can‚Äôt avoid it if going heavy because you can‚Äôt put big heavy loads on the fork.
data.author: Andy Simmons

data.text: Yes. I found the effect on the steering was more than the small load was worth.
data.author: Mike Kimber

data.text: Not recommend, it messes with your steering.

data.text: I‚Äôve ridden with them before & they ride great! Have you actually tried this setup?
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: I‚Äôve had front heavy front loaders and the bike handles awfully. I don‚Äôt use panniers because they restrict access through narrow spaces.
data.author: Lee Gray

data.text: centered over the axle and mounted low, they do not mess with steering. Yes, it's different, but not in a negative way because the bike still handles just fine.
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: that‚Äôs entirely dependent upon the geometry of your bike. Some bikes (those with low trail geometry) are designed specifically for front weight and a small load in the front improves the handling.

data.text: Wrong

data.text: used them the first time last week on an overnight trip with 80% off road on sand (dune) surfaces and single tracks in the woods. Went great, perfect! No obstruction of the weight. No rocky surfaces done so far, only smooth rolling tracks. Very happy with the setup
